$BTC  Bitcoin rotation season: are altcoins finally waking up?  Bitcoin has been setting the tone for the entire market, and every rotation out of BTC liquidity tends to ignite altcoin seasons. The big question is whether this rotation has real legs or is just another fake-out.  When Bitcoin dominates flows for weeks, liquidity usually gets crowded in one trade. At some point, early movers start rotating profits into altcoins, hunting for higher beta and narrative plays.  You can often see the first signs of rotation in large-cap alts like ETH, SOL or major L2 ecosystems. Volumes pick up, BTC dominance stalls or pulls back, and suddenly charts across sectors stop making new lows at the same time.  If this rotation sticks, it usually fans out from large caps to strong mid-caps, then into higher-risk plays like DeFi, infra and eventually memecoins. The further you go out on the risk curve, the more fragile the move becomes.  For traders and investors this matters because rotations rarely move in a straight line. Sharp BTC pullbacks can slam altcoins much harder, so chasing late can be painful even if the broader trend is still up.  The healthiest sign is when altcoin strength comes with real catalysts: protocol revenue, user growth, major launches, not just ‚Äúnumber go up‚Äù candles. Without that, rotations often fade as fast as they appeared.  #Altcoin Season#  #BTC Price Analysis#  #AltSeason  #Altcoin

After Bitcoin peaked in 2025, the market entered a correction phase that has lasted about 2 to 3 months, something normal and expected within an upward cycle. Historically, Bitcoin usually corrects 20% to 40% after significant peaks before rising again, and the current movement is exactly within this pattern.

Such corrections do not mean the end of the cycle, but rather a phase of profit-taking, consolidation, and accumulation. While the price maintains its bullish structure in the long term, these dips serve to strengthen the market and prepare for the next move. In previous cycles, Bitcoin spent a few months correcting and then returned to making new historical highs.

In short: what we are seeing now is healthy market behavior, not a collapse. Patience during this period is usually rewarded, because large upward movements generally come after these correction phases, when the market has already "breathed" and gained strength again.

One of the clearest signals across past crypto cycles is the relationship between stablecoin supply and altcoin momentum. When total stablecoin supply begins to rise, it usually means new capital is entering the market and waiting to be deployed. Historically, this has often aligned with a shift away from Bitcoin dominance and toward altcoins.


Right now, total stablecoin supply is turning up again after a long period of contraction. In previous cycles, this kind of inflection has marked the early stages of a transition ‚Äî not the top, but the point where risk appetite slowly starts to return.


At the same time, the OTHERS vs BTC chart (excluding the top 10) is extremely compressed. Altcoins have underperformed Bitcoin for years and are now sitting near the bottom of their historical range. From here, downside is increasingly limited unless the entire market breaks down.


In simple terms:
‚Ä¢ Altcoins are deeply washed out versus BTC
‚Ä¢ Sentiment is near extremes
‚Ä¢ Selling pressure has largely played out
‚Ä¢ Liquidity is quietly rebuilding


For those still holding, the hardest part is already behind you. At these levels, the main risk is no longer price ‚Äî it‚Äôs losing patience. When altcoins do reverse, history shows it usually happens quickly, not gradually.


This isn‚Äôt a call for blind buying or instant upside. It‚Äôs a reminder that markets turn when few expect it. Let the data guide you, not fear.
